Conference Track Manager - Documentation¶

Introduction¶

This library automates the planning of a big programming conference with many proposals which have passed the initial screen process and are only pending placement in a conference schedule.

  • Are you new to this? Check out the Build a docker image
  • Or go straight to the API Reference

Development Guide¶

Note

The instructions below assume that you have a bash console to your avail. It has been tested on MacOSX Sierra with Homebrew **1.1.9**

Features:

  • unit + functional tests with coverage report
  • Makefile targets to automate menial development tasks
  • Dockerfile that builds and tests the project in a sandboxed container
  • Auto-generated API documentation

Build a docker image¶

Note

Tested on Docker for Mac version 1.13.0 (5072)

docker build . -t tw-code-assignment
docker run tw-code-assignment

Preparing a local development environment¶

Ensure system dependencies:

Python 2.7.13
virtualenv 15.1.0
GNU Make 3.81

Run the automated build install targets:

make setup

Breakdown of installation commands:

# 1. Create and enter a virtual-env
virtualenv .venv

# 2. Enter the virtual-env
source .venv/bin/activate

# 3. Upgrade pip
pip install -U pip

# 4. Install local dependencies
pip install -r development.txt

Run the automated tests:

make tests

Instalation¶

python setup.py install

Command-Line Example¶

$ cat test-input.txt <<EOF
Writing Fast Tests Against Enterprise Rails 60min
Overdoing it in Python 45min
Lua for the Masses 30min
Ruby Errors from Mismatched Gem Versions 45min
Common Ruby Errors 45min
Rails for Python Developers lightning
Communicating Over Distance 60min
Accounting-Driven Development 45min
Woah 30min
Sit Down and Write 30min
Pair Programming vs Noise 45min
Rails Magic 60min
Ruby on Rails: Why We Should Move On 60min
Clojure Ate Scala (on my project) 45min
Programming in the Boondocks of Seattle 30min
Ruby vs. Clojure for Back-End Development 30min
Ruby on Rails Legacy App Maintenance 60min
A World Without HackerNews 30min
User Interface CSS in Rails Apps 30min
EOF
$ tw-conf-parse test-input.txt

API Reference¶

engine¶

class tw_conference_manager.engine.readers.TextReader[source]¶

Bases: object

Object that can parse lines containing descriptions and durations of proposed conference talks.

read_line(line)[source]¶

extracts metadata from a single line of text.

Parameters:line – a basestring
Returns:a dict containing the keys description and duration
Raises:InvalidLineError when the line does not contain a valid duration.
read_multiline(multiple_strings)[source]¶

parses a multi-line string. :returns: a list of dict as in read_line()

lightning_regex = <_sre.SRE_Pattern object>¶
minute_regex = <_sre.SRE_Pattern object>¶

models¶

class tw_conference_manager.models.Model(*args, **properties)[source]¶

Bases: object

Base model class, provides automatic attribute assignment, provides utilities for validating and transforming values of its fields.

Example:

from tw_conference_manager.models import Model

class Person(Model):
    __fields__ = (
        ('name', unicode),
        ('email', bytes),
    )

wole = Person('Wole', 'wole@thoughtworks.com')
assert wole.to_dict() == {
    'name': 'Wole',
    'email': 'wole@thoughtworks.com',
}
initialize(**cast_fields)[source]¶

this method gives an option for subclasses to take action upon instantiation.

In other words this is a post-validation constructor method.

to_dict()[source]¶

returns a dict containing the model fields

class tw_conference_manager.models.Talk(*args, **properties)[source]¶

Bases: tw_conference_manager.models.Model

Model for storing basic talk information: description and duration.

Provides a utility function to check whether the talk is a “lightning” one.

is_lightning()[source]¶
Returns:True if the duration is 5 or True
class tw_conference_manager.models.TalkList(*talks)[source]¶

Bases: list

A subclass of list with a shortcut method to parse a list of strings.

classmethod from_text(multiline_string)[source]¶

creates a new TalkList instance with talks parsed from the given parameter. :param multiline_string: a list of strings :returns: a new TalkList with Talk members

class tw_conference_manager.models.Session(*args, **properties)[source]¶

Bases: tw_conference_manager.models.Model

A model for declaring a session with start and end times.

Provides utility methods and properties to allocate talks and generate human-readable output.

allocate_talks(talks)[source]¶

Fills up an internal schedule with as many talks as possible.

Returns:a 2-item tuple containing a TalkList with allocated talks and another with remaining taiks.
initialize(starts_at, ends_at)[source]¶
to_lines()[source]¶
Returns:a human-readable list of strings with the allocated talks.
end_time¶
start_time¶
class tw_conference_manager.models.Track(*args, **properties)[source]¶

Bases: tw_conference_manager.models.Model

Model that contains 2 sessions, one holding a schedule for morning sessions and one for afternoon sessions, respectively.

allocate_talks(talks)[source]¶

Fills up an internal schedule with as many talks as possible on both morning and afternoon sessions.

initialize(number)[source]¶
to_lines()[source]¶
Returns:a human-readable list of strings with the allocated talks.
class tw_conference_manager.models.ConferenceTrackManager(*args, **properties)[source]¶

Bases: tw_conference_manager.models.Model

Model that takes care of all aspects of scheduling an unlimited list of talks into multiple tracks.

initialize(name, tracks=None)[source]¶
schedule_talks(talks)[source]¶

schedules all given talks into multiple tracks. :param talks: a TalkList with Talk instances :returns: a TalkList with all tracks currently scheduled

to_lines()[source]¶
Returns:a human-readable list of strings with the currently scheduled talks.
